title: Understanding Cognitive Load
subtitle: Why your brain gets tired when learning

layers.label: The Headline
layers.content: Your brain has limited mental energy for learning - when you exceed it, learning stops.

content.summary: Cognitive load theory explains why we can only process so much at once.

points.text: Working memory can only hold 4-7 items at a time
points.tooltip: Miller's Law - the 'magical number seven, plus or minus two'

points.text: New information competes for the same limited resources
points.tooltip: This is why multitasking while learning is ineffective

points.text: Well-designed learning breaks information into manageable chunks
points.tooltip: Called 'chunking' - a key instructional design principle

content.summary: There are three types of cognitive load, and only one is 'good' for learning.

points.text: Intrinsic load: The inherent difficulty of the material itself
points.tooltip: Can't be reduced - some things are just complex

points.text: Extraneous load: Unnecessary mental effort from poor design
points.tooltip: THIS is what instructional designers try to minimize

points.text: Germane load: Mental effort that builds lasting understanding
points.tooltip: The 'good' cognitive load - actual learning happening

points.text: Research by Sweller (1988) established these categories
points.tooltip: Cognitive Load Theory is one of the most validated theories in educational psychology
